A tangible way of affecting student life
is finally upon us. Next Tuesday, undergraduates will choose between two possible constitutions for the Student Council
and (hopefully) bring to a close the Council's thirteen-month quibble over its own
legitimacy.
Proposals 'B' and 'C' differ mainly in
spirit, not substance. Proposal 'B', authored by maverick Harry Lerner, is full
of reminders that "student officers serve
at the pleasure of their constituents." It
was drafted largely out of protest and often seems to berate the group it serves.
Proposal 'C', like the present Council who
wrote it, is wordier, more protective of
Council members, more aware of its own
consequences—and, not incidentally, more
comprehensive.
The similarities, then, are in content.
On the hotly debated "closed meetings"
issue, both proposals expressly prohibit
such meetings for the Council and most of
its groups. The structural requirements of
both proposals have only minor semantic
differences. President Steele's contention
that proposals 'A' (now defunct) and 'B'
are combined in 'C' is true—especially in
terms of content.

Dr. David Harvey
Dr. David Harvey is a professor in the Department of
Geography and Enviromental Engineering. He is teaching
two seminar classes.
(interviewed by Daisy Taylor)
N-L: Is class discussion
an efficient way to bring
across information in
your field? Is it useful to
what you teach'?
Harvey: I think it depends on the kind of
information you want to
impart. If there's a lot of
ractual information, then
obviously class discussion
-sn't a terribly good way
to do it unless you set
people in the class cer-:ain tasks, to get the
information, and then
they come in and
give you the information. But then there's other kinds
of information, particularly conceptual information,
ideas, which is very difficult to impart except by discussion. Because we can all use a concept like neighborhood or community, we all think we know what we
mean by it. But if you have discussion it becomes very
clear that everybody has a different interpretation.
If I talk about a concept of neighborhood, and I am
talking all the time and everybody's interpreting it in
their way then there is a failure of communication.
So I think it's very important when you're
dealing with concepts like that to discuss what they
mean, and via some kind of dialogue come to some
range of definitions. Clearly the more directly factual
material can be put across in another way, but I tend to
take the view that people can go and read that anywhere. It seems to me the important point of class
discussion is to complement the kind of factual reading
with a conceptual framework within which to interpret
those facts.
N-L: Do you feel that the quality or ease of class
discussion has varied over the years or in other universities where you have taught?
Harvey: I have never figured out why the quality varies
SO much. I think part of the reason behind it is that if

Dr. Lee Patterson, of the English Department, offers his
comments on class discussion in the context of the literature he teaches. He is currently teaching a seminar
course on the Epic.
Many, probably most of the contexts in which
literary conversation takes place are, and always have
been, institutional, places authorized by society for just
such aesthetic exchanges. One thinks not just of the
classroom but also ofthe salon, in all its historical guises,
or the Germanic or Achaian feasthall where a (preferably
blind) singer would chant the wisdom of the race. But
poets have taken pains to remind us that literature is also
able to constitute its own context, to prescribe if not to
control the terms ofits own reception. Sometimes these
terms are explicitly subversive - Paolo and Francesca
seduced by Arthurian tales, Emma Bovary immersed in
romantic novels - but at other times they define a
context that is itself social, itself an instructive alternative to our more usual settings. An early instance occurs
in Book XV of the Odyssey. Odysseus has returned to
lthaka disguised as a Cretan exile and finds shelter with
his swineherd Eumaios, and the two men pass the night
telling stories. Maintaining his disguise, Odysseus begins
with a tall tale that he fabricates in order to teach
Eumaios that suppliants like him are protected by the
gods, a fact that their hosts should remember. Eumaios'
response - the true story of his own sufferings - is
compelling in quite a different way. He knows the
lesson of hospitality perhaps better than does Odysseus:
a suppliant himself, he was taken in by Odysseus'
parents and nurtured as if her were their son, but who
(his story implies) will now care for him in his old age?

his homecoming is a responsibility that must be no
longer deferred or disguised, just as the context of
Eumaios' story offers a standard of social interdependence and generosity by which this homecoming must
be judged. For Eumaios and Odysseus together establish
a small version of the just society that Odysseus must
now seek to restore. "These nights are endless," Eumaios tells Odysseus, "and a man can sleep through
them. Or he can enjoy listening to stories:... we two,
sitting here in the shelter, eating and drinking, shall
entertain each other with remembering and telling our
sad sorrows." This episode as a whole is an image of
literary activity that can teach us much: one story that
calls forth another, truer one, and a dialogue that in its
very activity recovers the loss it laments. This is surely
the kind of response that the fiction that is the Odyssey
seeks to provoke, and the context it seeks to constitute.
It is one halfofa dialogue in which we must paritcipate,
and it reminds us that literature, and the reading of
literature, is finally a social activity.

spirit, not substance. Proposal 'B', authored by maverick Harry Lerner, is full
of reminders that "student officers serve
at the pleasure of their constituents." It

wrote it, is wordier, more protective of

consequences—and, not incidentally, more
comprehensive.
The similarities, then, are in content.
On the hotly debated "closed meetings"
issue, both proposals expressly prohibit
such meetings for the Council and most of
its groups. The structural requirements of
both proposals have only minor semantic
differences. President Steele's contention
that proposals 'A' (now defunct) and 'B'
are combined in 'C' is true—especially in

Dr. David Harvey
Dr. David Harvey is a professor in the Department of
Geography and Enviromental Engineering. He is teaching
two seminar classes.
(interviewed by Daisy Taylor)
N-L: Is class discussion
an efficient way to bring
across information in
your field? Is it useful to
what you teach'?
Harvey: I think it depends on the kind of
information you want to
impart. If there's a lot of
ractual information, then
obviously class discussion
-sn't a terribly good way
to do it unless you set
people in the class cer-:ain tasks, to get the
information, and then
they come in and
give you the information. But then there's other kinds
of information, particularly conceptual information,
ideas, which is very difficult to impart except by discussion. Because we can all use a concept like neighborhood or community, we all think we know what we
mean by it. But if you have discussion it becomes very
clear that everybody has a different interpretation.
If I talk about a concept of neighborhood, and I am
talking all the time and everybody's interpreting it in
their way then there is a failure of communication.
So I think it's very important when you're
dealing with concepts like that to discuss what they
mean, and via some kind of dialogue come to some
range of definitions. Clearly the more directly factual
material can be put across in another way, but I tend to
take the view that people can go and read that anywhere. It seems to me the important point of class
discussion is to complement the kind of factual reading
with a conceptual framework within which to interpret
those facts.
N-L: Do you feel that the quality or ease of class
discussion has varied over the years or in other universities where you have taught?
Harvey: I have never figured out why the quality varies
SO much. I think part of the reason behind it is that if
you allow a lot of class discussion and rely a lot on class
discussion you're never going to satisfy all the people all
of the time. There is certain sort of anarchistic tangential aspect to it ...you never know whether something is
tangential until you've followed it. You're constantly
trying to deal with a situation in which there is a certain
amount of chaos. I guess I take the view that it takes
a little chaos to do anything, and personally I'd rather
let the chaos flourish a bit and try to get something
creative out of it than to stick with the much more
authorian kind of lecture style.
N-L: What factors do you feel contribute to resistance
on the part of students to participating in class?
Harvey: Well, there's a whole range of personal factors.
Some people feel comfortable verbalizing, some don't.
There's a kind of tradition at certain schools; Hopkins
is kind of authoritarian in general. I think maybe
students here are not terribly familiar or used to the idea
of open class discussion or disagreeing with the professor
and having an argument with the professor and feeling
that they can do that without necessarily jeopardizing
their grade. Under those conditions most people won't
take on a professor and argue. The best discussions are
those where people are going to argue because that
sharpens both sides. But there's a natural resistance to
that and it takes a long time to get by that.
From the standpoint of the teacher, there's a real
difficulty in figuring out at what point you actually
intervene. The discussion is never entirely open: there's
always an authority there. At what point do you exert

your authority and cut a discussion off'? There's no
exact charter for saying when you should and when you
shouldn't. You play it by ear. So there's a barrier there
because you're always conscious and aware that even
though it's a reasonably open discussion and the students are discussing with each other, you're still the
reserve authority.
N-L: How long have you been teaching here?
Harvey: Ten years.
N-L: Have you always been using discussion and felt it
was important?
Harvey: I haven't given a lecture for I don't know how
long. I don't like to operate that way, partly because I
came here from Britain where it was all formal lecture
and there is absolutely no interaction at all with students. I think one of the things I valued about coming
here was that I could get away from that and try to
work in terms of class discussion, and work through
material through class discussion. That has to do with
the fact that I'm very much more interested now in
discussing concepts and ideas rather than factual information.
N-L: Is there anything you would like to add?
Harvey: It would be very interesting to get a very frank
appraisal from students as to how they think class
discussions go. I would be interested in that because I
never get a very frank appraisal of it. I would be very
surprised if you didn't have something like a 50%
discontent rate with any open discussion. But then
you're going to get some kind of discontent rate also
with the standard lecture format. The only difference is
that if you have a really good lecturer who can turn in
a performance and it's a sort of entertaining performance, you're entertained and you don't have to work at it
so much. But I think, particularly if the students take
the obligation to discuss seriously, you probably end up
learning more. Things that you are forced to discuss
really stick with you in ways that the entertaining
lecture doesn't. One of the things I found when I moved
from being a student to being a teacher is that I learned
much more from being a teacher than I ever learned
from being a student. I think one of the reasons I
wanted to shift to putting some of the burden of doing
the teaching on the students themselves is to try to make
them learn more. Whether it works or not, who knows.
One year you can use the same format as you used the
year before and it's a disaster, and the year before it was
terrific.

Dr. Lee Patterson, of the English Department, offers his
comments on class discussion in the context of the literature he teaches. He is currently teaching a seminar
course on the Epic.
Many, probably most of the contexts in which
literary conversation takes place are, and always have
been, institutional, places authorized by society for just
such aesthetic exchanges. One thinks not just of the
classroom but also ofthe salon, in all its historical guises,
or the Germanic or Achaian feasthall where a (preferably
blind) singer would chant the wisdom of the race. But
poets have taken pains to remind us that literature is also
able to constitute its own context, to prescribe if not to
control the terms ofits own reception. Sometimes these
terms are explicitly subversive - Paolo and Francesca
seduced by Arthurian tales, Emma Bovary immersed in
romantic novels - but at other times they define a
context that is itself social, itself an instructive alternative to our more usual settings. An early instance occurs
in Book XV of the Odyssey. Odysseus has returned to
lthaka disguised as a Cretan exile and finds shelter with
his swineherd Eumaios, and the two men pass the night
telling stories. Maintaining his disguise, Odysseus begins
with a tall tale that he fabricates in order to teach
Eumaios that suppliants like him are protected by the
gods, a fact that their hosts should remember. Eumaios'
response - the true story of his own sufferings - is
compelling in quite a different way. He knows the
lesson of hospitality perhaps better than does Odysseus:
a suppliant himself, he was taken in by Odysseus'
parents and nurtured as if her were their son, but who
(his story implies) will now care for him in his old age?
This is a moral imperative that suggests to Odysseus that
his homecoming is a responsibility that must be no
longer deferred or disguised, just as the context of
Eumaios' story offers a standard of social interdependence and generosity by which this homecoming must
be judged. For Eumaios and Odysseus together establish
a small version of the just society that Odysseus must
now seek to restore. "These nights are endless," Eumaios tells Odysseus, "and a man can sleep through
them. Or he can enjoy listening to stories:... we two,
sitting here in the shelter, eating and drinking, shall
entertain each other with remembering and telling our
sad sorrows." This episode as a whole is an image of
literary activity that can teach us much: one story that
calls forth another, truer one, and a dialogue that in its
very activity recovers the loss it laments. This is surely
the kind of response that the fiction that is the Odyssey
seeks to provoke, and the context it seeks to constitute.
It is one halfofa dialogue in which we must paritcipate,
and it reminds us that literature, and the reading of
literature, is finally a social activity.
